bug.author: omatai
bug.description:
Thank you for submitting a TensorFlow documentation issue. Per our GitHub policy, we only address code/doc bugs, performance issues, feature requests, and build/installation issues on GitHub. The TensorFlow docs are open source! To get involved, read the documentation contributor guide: <denchmark-link:https://www.tensorflow.org/community/contribute/docs>https://www.tensorflow.org/community/contribute/docs</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-h:h2>URL(s) with the issue:</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-link:https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#windows_1>https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#windows_1</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-h:h2>Description of issue (what needs changing): The documentation gives a command to "verify the install"... but NO clear indication of what should be the result. I get a list of 9 warnings (all CUDA-related) interspersed with 8 information messages. Finally there is a "tf.tensor(72.93745, shape=(), dtype=float32)" at the end. Is this correct? How would I know?</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-h:h3>Clear description</denchmark-h>
See above <denchmark-h:h3>Correct links</denchmark-h>
Is the link to the source code correct? n/a <denchmark-h:h3>Parameters defined</denchmark-h>
Are all parameters defined and formatted correctly? n/a <denchmark-h:h3>Returns defined</denchmark-h>
Are return values defined? n/a <denchmark-h:h3>Raises listed and defined</denchmark-h>
n/a <denchmark-h:h3>Usage example</denchmark-h>
Is there a usage example? Half of one - it lacks any output to check against, or instructions on how to interpret the result <denchmark-h:h3>Request visuals, if applicable</denchmark-h>
n/a <denchmark-h:h3>Submit a pull request?</denchmark-h>
No - I am far too new to github/tensorflow to ask sensible questions, let alone give sensible answers

comments.comment:
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/omatai>@omatai</denchmark-link> , When you run
if the code prints the tensor, in your case tf.tensor(72.93745, shape=(), dtype=float32), it means that TensorFlow was successfully imported. Please take a look at the breakdown of the code from this <denchmark-link:https://colab.research.google.com/gist/amahendrakar/9b82b578e1dacdfc3f097811963d392a/40959.ipynb>gist</denchmark-link> . Thanks!

OK - so you know that, and now I know that... but how will anyone else know that if it is not in the documentation? And how should all the information, warnings and errors be interpreted? When I follow the link you provide, it gives an error... which kinda makes it worse than when I first did it and only got warnings. So I'm not sure you have helped :-) The point is: all this needs to be in the documentation, not here, because nobody will ever find this again :-)

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/omatai>@omatai</denchmark-link> , Sorry for the confusion, the error was raised as I was running the code on CPU. Switching to GPU does not throw the error. Also, the logs are displayed based on the logging level. Changing the default log level does not print messages. Please check <denchmark-link:https://colab.research.google.com/gist/amahendrakar/185c45f1c1027f13699e3e700502fcbd/40959.ipynb>this updated gist</denchmark-link> for reference. Thanks!
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/omatai>@omatai</denchmark-link> , can you please send a PR to fix documentation?
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you.

@omatai, can you please send a PR to fix documentation?
I have no idea what is involved in a PR, no time available for several weeks to learn... and am deeply confused by why the results I got do not match the results shown by <denchmark-link:https://github.com/amahendrakar>@amahendrakar</denchmark-link> - I get a tensor with value 72.something; he gets -573 or something. If the purpose of the test is to validate the install, there needs to be a definitive and meaningful result. I am in no position to say what this result should be, nor how to interpret variations on it. Sorry - I have nothing constructive to contribute - I'm unsubscribing.

Hey, <denchmark-link:https://github.com/omatai>@omatai</denchmark-link> . The code example listed there is just a set of TF APIs that should run. Any non-error output is fine. The numbers don't match because you are summing a bunch of random numbers. It is expected that people using TF would at least know the public API. But anyway, we can change the test. Would you be ok if we replaced it with something like python3 -c "import tensorflow as tf; print(tf.constant("Everything installed successfully))? In this the output either contains "Everything installed successfully" (âœ…) or some error (so installation fails).

That certainly makes more sense than printing some random number and leaving people no advice on how to interpret it :-) But I would suggest it might be better to think about something that tests if the tensorflow installation is using GPU or CPU, and detects if that is installed correctly. As it turns out, I had installed the latest (incompatible) version of CUDA, so was not using GPU. When I ran my first heavy duty training, the CPU went to 100%, overheated and restarted my PC after 20 seconds. I don't know if what you suggest is sufficient to detect installation problems like that (CUDA is separate, after all...) but the computation recommended might be suitable. It just lacks any guidance as to how to interpret the result... which is clearly different on my machine from <denchmark-link:https://github.com/amahendrakar>@amahendrakar</denchmark-link> 's. That doesn't help anyone.

That is actually a good idea. I'll try to write a diagnose_me.py script over the weekend and then the verify instructions would be just python tools/diagnose_me.py or something like that. Thank you for the reminder for adding this tool (we have many DLL import failed issues that would be quickly solved by this).
As suggested by <denchmark-link:https://github.com/mihaimaruseac>@mihaimaruseac</denchmark-link> , I would like to work on making the diagnose_me.py script.

With the merging of <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/docs/pull/1749>tensorflow/docs#1749</denchmark-link> this can be now closed. For diagnose_me.py script, we should probably open a feature request.
